    Data Simulation from Multivariate Negative Binomial Distribution

    simData_mnegbinom.Rd

    This function simulates data with treatment and batch effects under different batch x treatment designs from multivariate negative binomial distribution using quantile-quantile transformation between multivariate normal and negative binomial distribution. This function can generate two or three batch groups.

    simData_mnegbinom(
  batch.group = 2,
  mean.batch,
  sd.batch = 1,
  mean.trt,
  sd.trt = 1,
  mean.bg = 0,
  sd.bg = 0.5,
  N,
  p_total,
  p_trt_relevant,
  p_bat_relevant,
  percentage_overlap_samples = 0.5,
  percentage_overlap_variables = 0.5,
  data.cor,
  disp = 10,
  prob_zero = 0,
  seeds = round(runif(1, 0, 999))
)

    Arguments

    batch.group

    Integer, the number of batch groups. Only valid for 2 or 3 batch groups. Default value is 2.

    mean.batch

    Numeric, the mean of batch effect coefficients for all related variables.

    sd.batch

    Numeric, the variability (standard deviation) of batch effect coefficients for all related variables.

    mean.trt

    Numeric, the mean of treatment effect coefficients for all related variables

    sd.trt

    Numeric, the variability (standard deviation) of treatment effect coefficients for all related variables.

    mean.bg

    Numeric, the mean of background noise.

    sd.bg

    Numeric, the variability (standard deviation) of background noise.

    N

    Integer, the number of samples.

    p_total

    Integer, the number of variables.

    p_trt_relevant

    Integer, the number of variables affected by treatment effects.

    p_bat_relevant

    Integer, the number of variables affected by batch effects.

    percentage_overlap_samples

    Numeric, in the range of \(0\) to \(1\), the percentage of samples from one batch group in one treatment group.

    percentage_overlap_variables

    Numeric, in the range of \(0\) to \(1\), the percentage of variables with both batch and treatment effects given fixed number of variables with each effect.

    data.cor

    Correlation matrix. The correlation between each pair of variables.

    disp

    Numeric. The dispersion parameter of negative binomial distribution.

    prob_zero

    Numeric, in the range of \(0\) to \(1\). The probability of each value to be 0.

    seeds

    Integer. Default value is randomly selected from \(0\) to \(999\).

    Value

    simData_mnegbinom returns a list that contains the following components:

    data

    The simulated data.

    cleanData

    The ground-truth data without the batch effect.

    data_mu_matrix

    The \(ln\) value of the mean to model negative binomial distribution for the simulated data.

    clean_mu_matrix

    The \(ln\) value of the mean to model negative binomial distribution for the ground-truth data.

    Y.trt

    The simulated outcome variable indicating the treatment grouping information.

    Y.bat

    The simulated outcome variable indicating the batch grouping information.

    true.trt

    The variables assigned with the treatment effect.

    true.batch

    The variables assigned with the batch effect.

    zero_index

    The indexes of cells containing the resulting counts from the Multivariate Negative Binomial Distribution that are inflated as zero.

    References

    Wang Y, Lê Cao K (2020). “A multivariate method to correct for batch effects in microbiome data.” bioRxiv.

    Author

    Yiwen Wang, Kim-Anh Lê Cao

    Examples

    ## Not run:
## First example
## To simulate the correlation structure
data.cor.res = corStruct(p = 300, zero_prob = 0.7)

## Balanced batch x treatment design
simulation <- simData_mnegbinom(mean.batch = 7,
                                sd.batch = 8,
                                mean.trt = 3,
                                sd.trt = 2,
                                mean.bg = 0,
                                sd.bg = 0.2,
                                N = 40,
                                p_total = 300,
                                p_trt_relevant = 100,
                                p_bat_relevant = 200,
                                percentage_overlap_samples = 0.5,
                                percentage_overlap_variables = 0.5,
                                data.cor = data.cor.res$data.cor,
                                disp = 10,
                                prob_zero = 0,
                                seeds = 1)

## Second example
## Unbalanced batch x treatment design
simulation <- simData_mnegbinom(mean.batch = 7,
                                sd.batch = 8,
                                mean.trt = 3,
                                sd.trt = 2,
                                mean.bg = 0,
                                sd.bg = 0.2,
                                N = 40,
                                p_total = 300,
                                p_trt_relevant = 100,
                                p_bat_relevant = 200,
                                percentage_overlap_samples = 0.2,
                                percentage_overlap_variables = 0.5,
                                data.cor = data.cor.res$data.cor,
                                disp = 10,
                                prob_zero = 0,
                                seeds = 1)
## End(Not run)
